intro: Echinochloa crus-galli var. stagnina, commonly known as swamp稗, is a perennial grass species native to wetland habitats. It typically grows in shallow water or moist soil, often found in marshes, ditches, and along the edges of ponds. The plant has slender, erect stems that can reach up to 1 meter in height, with narrow, linear leaves. Its inflorescence consists of spikelets that are often submerged or floating, adapting to aquatic environments. This variant is characterized by its ability to thrive in waterlogged conditions, making it an important component of wetland ecosystems.
